bioghist.p: Clinton Bowman (b. 1890) was a Presbyterian minister. He was a 1915 graduate of Louisville Theological Seminary, and served as a minister in churches in Oklahoma and Illinois. During World War I, he was a chaplain in the U.S. Army. In 1925 he was called to be pastor of the First Presbyterian in East St. Louis. The congregation was divided for a time in the 1950s, with Rev. Bowman and a minority of the congregation remaining at the church's original site, while the majority of the congregation moved to a new site to the southeast. The group led by Bowman became the Westminster Presbyterian Church of East St. Louis on January 31, 1953. The two congregations merged in 1957.

scopecontent.p: This is collection of papers of Clinton Bowman. Materials include: typed sermons, with some notes, 1925-1954 (9 cubic feet); scrapbook of newspaper clippings, programs, and announcements of marriages performed by Rev. Bowman, 1914-1917; minutes, memoranda, and correspondence related to Bowman's position on the Board of Trustees of Washington College; a small amount of correspondence related to church matters in St. Louis; and photographs of Bowman. The collection also contains materials related to Bowman's service as a chaplain for the 141st Infantry during World War I, including memos, orders, correspondence, photographs, postcards, maps, uniform patches, artifacts, and copies of the Stars and Stripes, the Washington Times, and the East St. Louis Times from 1918 and 1919.
